citations.narrative:
The maximum number of animals authorized for the licensee's USDA license is 250, but they currently have 259 dogs.
The USDA license authorizes a specific number of animals to ensure the facility is capable of providing care for that
number of animals.
A licensee must obtain a new license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand
at any single point in time during the period of licensure. The licensee must maintain no more than the maximum number
of animals that their USDA license allows.
To be corrected by: 24-May-2024

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee failed to do adequate daily observations of two dogs with medical conditions.
-A female Cavalier King Charles Spaniel "Willow" MC# 0840 had a large irregularly shaped wound approximately 5 inches
by 3 inches on her right side. The wound exposes fresh, moist, reddened tissue where the skin had rolled away. There is
a creamy white to yellow discharge along the top edge of the wound along the back of the dog and covering
approximately 70% of the open wound. The edges of the wound have curled back and appear dry in some areas. The hair
around the wound is matted and wet in appearance. Another wound was found on the right side of the dog's neck
approximately 2 inches by 2 inches in size. The edges of this wound appear dry with a pocket forming under the skin. The
tissue inside this wound appears reddened and moist. The facility representatives stated this dog did not look like this
yesterday during daily observations and that this dog has been housed with female Bichon "Luna" for approximately one
week with no issues observed.
-A female Bichon "Luna" MC#6100 and #3389 was found in poor dental health. One canine tooth could be observed with
a receding gum line that was reddened, inflamed with a spot of blood visible. The inspector was unable to examine the
teeth more closely due to the dog reacting painfully to the exam. The licensee stated this is abnormal behavior for this
dog.
Severe soft tissue injuries and poor dental health may lead to pain, distress and further systemic problems for the
animals. Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include adequate
daily observations of all animals to assess their health and well-being. These dogs must be evaluated by a licensed
veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective treatment plan in writing. This treatment plan must be
made available for APHIS inspection. The dogs were taken to the attending veterinarian during the inspection.
To be corrected by: End of Business 24-April-2024.

Two female Bichons were present in an outdoor exercise yard and had no access to water. The inspector watched the
dogs go back to their primary enclosures where they did not show interest in water. Dogs that do not have access to
water may become dehydrated and reduced water consumption may lead to additional medical problems.
Potable water must be continuously available for the health and well-being of the dogs, unless restricted by the attending
veterinarian.
To be corrected by: 24-April-2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility has not been sanitizing as often as necessary to prevent an accumulation of organic debris in primary
enclosures. In at least 7 primary enclosures housing at least 14 dogs, there is a light to medium brown film of organic
material on the plastic dog doors. Failure to sanitize enclosures often enough to prevent an accumulation of debris may
increase the risk of disease hazards towards the dogs.
Used primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for dogs must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks and
more often if necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. Hard
surfaces must be sanitized using one of the following methods: live steam under pressure or washing with hot water (at
least 180° F) and soap or detergent. The licensee must clean and sanitize the primary enclosures and ensure that all
aspects of the enclosure are maintained in a clean and sanitized condition in order to support the health of the dogs.

The licensee is missing medical records for 2 adults and 1 puppy. Two adult dogs, "Midnight Dancer" and "Havana", are
missing their distemper and parvovirus vaccine dates as well as their deworming dates. A Shihpoo puppy born 30-
January-2024 had a vaccine reaction approximately 2 weeks ago with hair loss, the attending veterinarian was contacted
and instructed to keep separate and monitor hair loss improvement. No records were available about the description and
the attending veterinarian's care instructions. The lack of medical records makes it difficult to determine if the animals are
receiving vaccinations, deworming and treatment plans. This information is needed for APHIS inspectors to ensure the
medical care is being provided by the facility.
The licensee must maintain complete and maintain updated medical records including the identity of the animal, including
identifying marks, tattoos, or tags on the animal and the animal’s breed, sex, and age; Provided, however, that routine
husbandry, such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, or treatments, performed on all animals in a group (or
herd), may be kept on a single record.
To be corrected by: 24-April-2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.1(b)(2)(i) 
   
Requirements and application 
The maximum number of animals authorized for the licensee's USDA license is 250, but they currently have 259 dogs. 
The USDA license authorizes a specific number of animals to ensure the facility is capable of providing care for that 
number of animals. 
A licensee must obtain a new license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand 
at any single point in time during the period of licensure. The licensee must maintain no more than the maximum number 
of animals that their USDA license allows. 
To be corrected by: 24-May-2024 
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee failed to do adequate daily observations of two dogs with medical conditions.  
-A female Cavalier King Charles Spaniel "Willow" MC# 0840 had a large irregularly shaped wound approximately 5 inches

tissue inside this wound appears reddened and moist. The facility representatives stated this dog did not look like this

week with no issues observed. 
-A female Bichon "Luna" MC#6100 and #3389 was found in poor dental health. One canine tooth could be observed with 
a receding gum line that was reddened, inflamed with a spot of blood visible. The inspector was unable to examine the

Severe soft tissue injuries and poor dental health may lead to pain, distress and further systemic problems for the

To be corrected by: End of Business 24-April-2024. 
3.10(a) 
   
Watering 
Two female Bichons were present in an outdoor exercise yard and had no access to water. The inspector watched the 
dogs go back to their primary enclosures where they did not show interest in water. Dogs that do not have access to 
water may become dehydrated and reduced water consumption may lead to additional medical problems. 
Potable water must be continuously available for the health and well-being of the dogs, unless restricted by the attending 
veterinarian. 
To be corrected by: 24-April-2024 
3.11(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The facility has not been sanitizing as often as necessary to prevent an accumulation of organic debris in primary 
enclosures. In at least 7 primary enclosures housing at least 14 dogs, there is a light to medium brown film of organic 
material on the plastic dog doors. Failure to sanitize enclosures often enough to prevent an accumulation of debris may 
increase the risk of disease hazards towards the dogs. 
Used primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for dogs must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks and

least 180° F) and soap or detergent. The licensee must clean and sanitize the primary enclosures and ensure that all 
aspects of the enclosure are maintained in a clean and sanitized condition in order to support the health of the dogs. 
3.13(b)(1) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is missing medical records for 2 adults and 1 puppy. Two adult dogs, "Midnight Dancer" and "Havana", are 
missing their distemper and parvovirus vaccine dates as well as their deworming dates. A Shihpoo puppy born 30-
January-2024 had a vaccine reaction approximately 2 weeks ago with hair loss, the attending veterinarian was contacted

The licensee must maintain complete and maintain updated medical records including the identity of the animal, including 
identifying marks, tattoos, or tags on the animal and the animal’s breed, sex, and age; Provided, however, that routine 
husbandry, such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, or treatments, performed on all animals in a group (or 
herd), may be kept on a single record. 
To be corrected by: 24-April-2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
